One recent example of a geopolitical event that had a significant impact on the global economy was the trade dispute between the United States and China. The trade tensions between the two largest economies in the world began in 2018 when the US imposed tariffs on several Chinese goods to address its perceived trade imbalance with China. China responded with retaliatory tariffs on US goods. The trade dispute escalated over time, with both sides raising tariffs on each other's goods and taking other measures such as blacklisting companies and restricting technology transfers.

This trade dispute had several impacts on the global economy. Firstly, it disrupted global supply chains, as many manufacturers relied on goods from both countries in their production processes. This resulted in higher costs for businesses and consumers, leading to lower economic growth. Secondly, the conflict increased uncertainty in the global economy, making businesses and investors more cautious about making long-term investment decisions. Finally, the trade dispute also had ramifications on currency values, as the uncertainty led to fluctuations in exchange rates.

As the trade dispute continued, it became evident that it was having a significant impact on the global economy, and several organizations such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund lowered their global growth forecasts as a result. Eventually, the two countries signed a partial trade deal in December 2019, which helped to ease tensions and restore some confidence in the global economy.
